title: FIFA president Gianni Infantino wants the 2026 World Cup to be hosted by 'three or four' countries

FIFA president Gianni Infantino is keen for the 2026 World Cup to be hosted by up to four countries. 
Co-hosted tournaments have taken place in the past — the 2002 World Cup was staged in Japan and South Korea — but never by more than two nations. 
But Infantino, who replaced the disgraced Sepp Blatter as the head of FIFA just under a year ago, feels shared responsibility is the future. 
The former general secretary of UEFA believes the financial burden of hosting should be spread across multiple nations while also stressing they should be located close to each other for logistical reasons. 
Speaking in Qatar, Infantino said: "We will encourage co-hosting for the World Cup because we need FIFA to show we are reasonable and we have to think about sustainability long-term. 
"It is perfectly in line with our sustainability and legacy to maybe bring together two, three, four countries who can jointly present a project with three, four, five stadiums each. 
"We will certainly encourage it. Ideally the countries will be close to each other for the sake of ease of travel." Like us on Facebook
